docs.lead_paragraph: THE WOMAN FROM HAMBURG And Other True Stories. By Hanna Krall. Translated by Madeline G. Levine. 260 pp. Other Press. $19.
docs.snippet: Hanna Krall uses the methods of fiction to get at the truth of the Holocaust.

docs.lead_paragraph: After two test starts in the 100-meter preliminaries Friday, Marion Jones simply walked away. She withdrew from the United States track and field championships, saying through associates that she had a strained quadriceps in her left leg. The pressing question now is whether the end of this meet will also represent the end of her career as a top international sprinter. Jones also pulled out of the 200 meters and lost any chance of qualifying for the world championships in Helsinki, Finland, in August. In her absence, Lisa Barber won the women's 100 yesterday in 11.10 seconds.

headline.main: Jones's Exit at Nationals Stirs Doubts

docs.snippet: A weekend that was billed as a planned restoration of Marion Jones to the top of women's sprinting has instead backfired.

byline.original: By JERE LONGMAN; James Dunaway contributed reporting from Carson, Calif., for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: A headline in some copies yesterday with an article about the New York Senate's approval of a bill concerning sales of the morning-after pill, which can prevent pregnancy after sex, misstated a provision. It lets pharmacists and nurses dispense the pill to women who lack prescriptions by using blanket prescription forms obtained from doctors that name no individual patient; it does not allow over-the-counter sales.
docs.abstract: Correction of headline with June 23 article on New York Senate's approval of bill concerning sales of morning-after pill to prevent pregnancy
docs.snippet: A headline in some copies yesterday with an article about the New York Senate's approval of a bill concerning sales of the morning-after pill, which can prevent pregnancy after sex, misstated a provision. It lets pharmacists and nurses dispense the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a heartening advance with national reverberations, the Republican-led New York State Senate approved a bill on Wednesday that will permit local pharmacists to dispense emergency contraceptives to women who do not have a prescription. The surprising 34-to-27 vote, which followed easy approval by the Democratic-led Assembly, catapults the issue to a noncommittal Gov. George Pataki. Mr. Pataki has no principled course but to sign it. The measure is a necessary response to the ideological gridlock at the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. is still stalling over granting all American women over-the-counter access to the morning-after contraceptive known as Plan B, a step overwhelmingly supported by the agency's advisory panels in 2003 and by the existing scientific evidence. Under the bill, participating New York pharmacists and registered nurses would be able to obtain blanket prescriptions from doctors that name no individual patient, and dispense the pills to women and girls of any age.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises Republican-led New York State Senate for approving bill that will permit local pharmacists to dispense emergency contraceptives to women without presecriptons, and calls on Gov George Pataki to sign measure rather than try to score points with his party's far right by vetoing it
docs.snippet: Gov. George Pataki has no principled course but to sign a bill that will permit pharmacists to dispense emergency contraception without prescriptions.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican-led State Senate passed a bill on Wednesday that would allow pharmacists and nurses to dispense the so-called morning-after pill, which can prevent pregnancy after sex, to women who do not have prescriptions. Since the Democratic-led State Assembly has already passed the bill, it will now be sent to Gov. George E. Pataki, who will have to decide whether to sign it. Seven other states have similar laws.

headline.main: Bill Allows Sales of Pill Over Counter

docs.snippet: The State Senate passed a bill on that would allow pharmacists and nurses to dispense the so-called morning-after pill to women who do not have prescriptions.

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER and MARC SANTORA

docs.lead_paragraph: A Law Backfires, Leaving Romanian Orphans in Limbo To protect children, Romania effectively banned international adoptions, which were popular with American and European applicants. The children may spend their lives in orphanages, like this one in Bucharest. PAGE A6 U.A.W. Chief to Face G.M. Ron Gettelfinger, the president of United Auto Workers, faces the fight of his union life as Rick Wagoner, General Motors' chief executive, presses him to accept major benefit cuts. The fight will have broad implications for the American autoworker and help determine whether the Big Three automakers can slash costs. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Religion at Military Academy An Air Force panel found that officers and faculty members at the Air Force Academy periodically used their positions to promote Christian beliefs and failed to accommodate the religious needs of non-Christian cadets. But it said it found no ''overt religious discrimination.'' PAGE A12 New Social Security Proposal Influential Republicans offered a proposal that would use the cash surplus the Social Security system is running to finance private investment accounts. PAGE A13 Mayor Wins on Trash Plan After an earlier victory, the City Council abandoned its fight against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's ambitious plan to ship New York City's garbage by barge. But the plan still faces significant hurdles. PAGE B1 Global Warming Pioneer Dies Dr. Charles D. Keeling, who set off current concerns over global warming through his ''Keeling curve'' measurements that, starting in the 1950's, showed a steady rise in the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, was 77. PAGE C20 Gain for Morning-After Pill Senators in Albany passed a bill to allow pharmacists and nurses to dispense the so-called morning-after pill, which can prevent pregnancy after sex, to women who do not have prescriptions. PAGE B1 Little Data on Health Devices Patients are receiving less information on products that are implanted in their bodies than on the safety and performance of their cars. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Dressed to Fly This travel season, savvy passengers have figured out how to pass through airport security checkpoints without incident. Chic this summer at the airport means no lace-up dress shoes, no belts and no heavy-metal jewelry. THURSDAY STYLES, PAGE G1
